thread.title: Avoid traffic, crowds with back door into Yosemite
thread.title_full: Avoid traffic, crowds with back door into Yosemite - San Francisco Chronicle

author: By Andy Murdock
title: Avoid traffic, crowds with back door into Yosemite
text:
Photo: Andy Murdock, Special To The Chronicle 8123989|article-6402593|7 8123989|article-6402593|1 email_share_embed|photo-8123989|article-6402593|1 8123989|article-6402593|2 8123989|article-6402593|3 8123989|article-6402593|4 8123989|article-6402593|5 google_share_embed|photo-8123989|article-6402593|6 Trumbull Lake looking toward the campground. Trumbull Lake looking toward the campground.
It’s summer in Yosemite: Cue slow parades of cars around the valley floor, accommodations that book up many months in advance, crowded view points. The other side of Yosemite — the other 99 percent of the more than 1,100 square miles of pristine, and mostly people-free, Sierra Nevada wilderness — is almost exclusively the domain of backpackers. Almost, but not completely. Trumbull Lake looking toward the campground. Trumbull Lake looking toward the campground.

Almost, but not completely.
